project: Cicero Health Center Relocation
Clean Steam Piping Replacement
description:
DESCRIPTION

This project will repair and replace corroded piping and components on the clean steam system at the John H. Stroger Jr. Hospital of Cook County (JSH). 

The Hospital has two separate steam producing systems, heating and clean steam. The central boiler plant, used to generate steam for heat, is a closed system. Condensate is pumped back to the central boiler plant, treated and reused. The central boiler plant feeds the clean steam system. Clean steam is then generated by six independent generators. 

The clean steam condensate lines, components and fittings have been subject to severe corrosion and leaks. Continuous problems and damage include but are not limited to:
* Deterioration of the supply and condensate piping, threaded joints, elbows, steam traps, jacketed kettles, etc.
* Staining and corrosion in Autoclaves and kitchen equipment and staining of sterilized medical equipment and utensil
* Humidifiers leaking into the ductwork and hospital spaces and improperly sized humidifiers
* Clogged steam generator tube bundles

ENGINEERING CONSULTANT:
WMA Consultant Engineers, Ltd.

project: CORE Center, Roof - Replace Air Cooled System
description:
The existing Chiller at the Core Center has reached the end of its useful life. The Chiller has been in place since the building was constructed in 1998. The chilling capacity on the unit is approximately 400 Tons. 

While the Chiller is still in operation, it is not operating as efficiently and effectively to meet the designed cooling loads. With the Core Center primarily handling of infectious diseases, the unit needs to be replaced in order to ensure that the Core Center can maintain a temperature controlled environment. 

The scope of this project includes: 

Design of a new Chiller System
Calculating mechanical, electrical, and structural loads
Removal of the existing Chiller System
Patching wall penetrations 
Repair / Replace existing pipe supports and hangers
Cleaning & patching abandoned pipes in the walls & ceilings
Replacement of existing pipe valves, conduits, and panels

description:
The Countywide Fire & Life Safety System Upgrades Package Number 9:

This package includes the following facilities:
Div. 5, Div. 11 and South Campus Building-3 at the DOC campus; District 5/Markham, Courthouse 

The fire alarm & detection systems are over twelve (12) years old at each of the facilities; the ?Life Cycle? of fire alarm & detection systems is 12-15 years span. The current systems as a whole requires updating due to aged components and replacement parts are difficult to obtain. In addition, modifications of spaces in the facility require that system to be reconfigured to assure that all fire and supervisory alarm signals are accurately indicated on the control panels.

The project scope of work includes the following, but not limited to:
? Provide a new annunciator panel.
? Replace the fire control monitoring system, including the data gathering panels, the detection devices & supervisory systems for suppression systems to assure complete integrity of the system.
? New and/upgrading of all exit lights.
? Provide audible and visual signaling devices.
? Address interior stairs for conformance with the Chicago Stairwell Ordinance.

description:
The objective of this project consists of implementing a uniform Countywide Time & Attendance system with the following requirements:

?Phasing-in a Countywide, attendance and scheduling system at all Cook County facilities.
?Establish a single system capable of combining time and effort tracking, FLSA (Fair Labor Standards Act), FMLA (Family Medical Leave Act) and personal leave reporting into one system, to significantly reduce the amount of time an employee spends reporting time. 
?Providing easier, automated access through remote availability and device driven technologies to schedule, record attendance and capture time.
?Increasing visibility and reporting of scheduling, attendance and time information for employees and managers to review.
?Planning for a system integrating with Accounting and HR/Payroll Systems.
?Producing standard reports to be exported into standard file formats to capture time data for input into payroll systems.

project: Guaranteed Energy Performance Contracting Project - JCI
description:
DESCRIPTION

This contract provides guaranteed energy performance evaluations at the Cook County John H. Stroger Hospital Campus. 

The goal of the project is to identify and implement energy conservation measures (ECMs) that will result in at least a 10% reduction in emissions and energy costs compared to a baseline year, throughout a 15 year financing period. 

Phase 1 consists of a comprehensive investment grade audit of 13 buildings on the Department of Corrections and Juvenile Temporary Detention Center East and West buildings. If the ECMs identified are determined to achieve cost savings sufficient to cover financing and implementaiton of the ECMs, the parties may negotiate Phase 2 , In Phase 2, Noresco, LLC will perform engineering and construction services to provide and implement the cost savings measures.

If adequate cost savings to cover the financing costs cannot be identified, the County has no obligation to pay for the audit. If adequate savings are identified but the County chooses not to enter into a GEPC or chooses not to finance the conservation measures, the County will pay the actual cost of the audit not to exceed a predetermined limit.

Phase 1 consists of a comprehensive investment grade audit of 13 buildings on the Department of Corrections and Juvenile Temporary Detention Center East and West buildings. If the ECMs identified are determined to achieve cost savings sufficient to cover financing and implementaiton of the ECMs, the parties may negotiate Phase 2 , In Phase 2, Noresco, LLC will perform engineering and construction services to provide and implement the cost savings measures.

project: Hawthorne Warehouse
description:
Build-out of 371,000 square feet of space within the Hawthorne Warehouse to accommodate general storage and records management complete with administrative operations for the Clerk of the Circuit Court, County Clerk, and the Bureau of Health. Perform space programming for the space vacated by the Clerk of the Circuit Court for other Cook County agencies at the Rockwell Warehouse.

Implementation of an exhaust system for the building to equalize the temperature and optimize indoor air quality
Replacement of inoperable HVAC units to maintain the operations of the 3-story office building.  
Development of electrical as-built distribution single line diagram for use to determine abandoned systems and code compliance; and design of electrical closet placement
Replacement of existing lighting and consideration of solar panels to operate lighting
Renovated plumbing system throughout the building which will include work to make bathrooms ADA compliant.
Comprehensive security system and egress plan for means of public access and security and safety of the building.  

This project also consists of resurfacing approximately 220,000 square feet of parking lot for approximately 500 parking spaces, design of a security guard station with entrance control, lighting, signage, and landscaping.

Creation of enough parking spaces to accommodate the needs of the County Clerk, the Clerk of the Circuit Court, the Bureau of Health, Facilities Management, outside contractors and the general public.

Installation of a security guard station with the proper entrance controls in order to screen all vehicle traffic onto the premises. The station shall be completed in a way to minimize traffic congestion and allow an adequate turn radius for large trucks from the street 

For the safety of all County employees, contractors, and guests at the Hawthorne Warehouse campus, we will install a high mast lighting system utilizing high intensity discharge (HID) lamps throughout the entire parking lot.

Proper signage will be installed to correspond with striped drive lanes throughout the lot to ensure that visitors have a clear understanding of how to get to their desired location at the Warehouse.

Installation of adequate landscaping for beautification of the property.

project: New RTU/RCDC Project at the DOC
description:
PROJECT DESCRIPTION:

This project will provide a new 283,000 square foot Residential Treatment Unit (RTU) and Reception, Classification, Diagnostic Center (RCDC) at the Department of Corrections.

This new facility will efficiently respond to the demand of increasing numbers of detainee admissions and mental health evaluations and treatment in a secure, contemporary, well-organized intake and state of the art medical screening facility.

The facility will meet current ?Essential Standards? set by the National Commission on Correctional Health Care and the American Correctional Association as required for maintaining accreditation and recommendations by the Department of Justice

The existing RCDC and RTU facilities can no longer accommodate the volume of admissions, screenings and care required. The facilities are overcrowded, basic amenities are inadequate, building systems are outdated and detainee movement throughout the process is cumbersome due to lack of space and inefficient work and holding areas. 

The RCDC processes new admissions into the Department of Correction and detainees going to and from court for all six branches of the Circuit Courts of Cook County. The number of detainees processed through the RCDC can average 1,500 individuals on a single busy day.

The RTU provides a range of medical and mental health evaluation and treatment services for individuals within the criminal justice system, from the point of arrest through incarceration to release. New admissions receive medical and psychological screenings upon arrival in the RCDC. The RTU houses detainees who present during pre-screening in the RCDC with mental health concerns and provides residential intermediate care and twenty-four hour crisis and intervention services. The RTU also houses detainees from other divisions in the jail who develop mental health issues during incarceration.

project: RFQ: CMA for RTU-RCDC at the DOC
description:
DESCRIPTION

This purpose of this RFQ is to establish a pool of qualified consultants with the qualifications to provide professional construction administration services for the new RTU-RCDC building located at the Department of Corrections. 

The project is an $84 million dollar construction project currently under construction. A construction management administrator to protect the interests of the County and oversee the project (including installation of furniture and medical equipment) through to occupancy is deemed to be in the best interest of the County.

project: RFQ: Exterior Wall & Enclosure Inspection Services
description:
DESCRIPTION

This purpose of this RFQ is to establish a pool of qualified consultants with the qualifications to provide inspections of exterior walls and enclosures. The County has a wide variety of building types:

Building types include, but are not limited to, small garage type storage buildings, medium/large industrial type warehouses, detention buildings, hospitals, courthouses and administration buildings.

Materials of construction vary and include, but are not, limited to masonry, limestone, concrete, terra cotta, steel, pre-cast and poured concrete panels, aluminum, glass, wood and other materials.

Building sizes vary from one hundred (100) square feet to one million five hundred thousand (1,500.000) square feet and from one (1) story to thirty six (36) stories in height.

Consultants who wish to be part of the qualified pool will need to be able to:

* Provide Visual and critical inspections and reports required by code

*Provide the equipment with which to conduct the inspections

* Provide inspections to determine unstable facade conditions, prioritization of repair

*Develop design and construction documents and perform related construction phase administration

project: Security Checkpoint Upgrade at DOC
Security Post Construction Upgrade
description:
DESCRIPTION:

This project will expand and renovate Posts 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 and Div. 4 at the Department of Corrections (DOC).

The intent of the project is to faciltate the processing of visitor traffic entering the DOC. Three posts will be expanded and the remaining posts will undergo renovation including improved lightning. 

Post 5 is used by all employees, visiting peace officers and inividuals visiting detainees. The existing post is too small 
to efficiently to check visitor identification, remove contraband and allow safely que individuals to advance through metal detectors and scanners. During busy hours as many as 100 individuals may wait to be processed for admittance. The work for Post V will include a covered walkway. 

Post 7 is used by vendors with vehilcles, employees and visitors. This Post will be enlarged to allow for to provider more efficient and better security inspection of vehicles to assure that contraband does not enter the jail.

Post 8 processes detainee transport buses and truck supplies into the DOC. Lighting and gates will be improved at this post.

Post 10 will be eliminated and combined with the new Post 9.

project: Stroger Hospital Automatic Transfer Swithces
Stroger Hospital Polymer Epoxy Flooring
description:
The existing sheet vinyl flooring is the original flooring finish in the Central Sterile Processing area in  the hospital and has been in use for 9-years, since the hospital opened in 2002. Due to the wear and tear, the sheet vinyl has many tears and splits. Also, the underlayment in some areas has deteriorated. Many areas of the flooring has delaminated and bubbled, this makes it difficult or impossible to repair properly.

In the Central Sterile Processing area, contaminated surgical tools, used instruments and other materials are received throughout the hospital, sterilized and assembled for the re-use in surgeries and other clinical procedures. It is necessary that finishes in the Central Sterile Processing, including flooring, possess qualities to promote cleanliness and enhance infection control.

Based on the hospital's experience with the existing sheet vinyl flooring, we have reached the conclusion that a more durable epoxy flooring in the CSP area is necessary to meet the above objective. The epoxy flooring will be easier to maintain and with a longer expected service life, will be more cost effective long term.

project: Vechicle Storage Facility at Oak Forest Hospital
description:
DESCRIPTION

Substantial Completion for this project was Feburary 11, 2011. Warrantees expire February 11, 2012.
 
This Design-Build project will provide a 6,400 square foot facility at Oak Forest Hospital for the Cook County Department of Public Health. The facility will house specialized emergency command and mobile medical vehicles in a secure enviroment in order to protect and extend the life of the customized equipment. It will facilitate loading equipment and supplies in emergencies and inclement weather and include ?on-shore? power receptacles for recharging on board systems; vehicle maintenance document storage; storage room(s) for restocking the vehicle; and sirens for emergency exiting. The gate to an existing chain link fence on Cicero avenue will be modified to provide an electric sliding gate to facilitate emergency exits and entries.

project: Video Visitation Center at DOC and Outlying Courthouses
Women's Justice Services Center at DOC
description:
DESCRIPTION:

This project will provide a new home in Divisoin VII for the Cook County Sheriff's Women's Justice Programs located at the Department of Corrections Campus (DOC). It iwll consolidate the WJS program, currently housed in various locations throughout the DOC campus, making it a more efficent program.

Division VII, constructed in the early 1900s, will provide a modern, safe and efficient environment where women who choose to participate in the program can undergo rehabilitation and learn new skills to allow them to become productive and valued members of society.

The consolidation will facilitate the program's services to its clients; provide continuity between the two phases of the WJSC program (residential treatment and training); and provide living and training environments in compliance with Department of Justice mandates and Illinois Jail Standards. 

The Project includes but is not limited to civil/site, architectural, structural, HVAC, electrical, plumbing, telecommunications / structured wiring, security and fire protection and sprinkler systems, landscaping, new furniture, fixtures and equipment. This building will incorporate ?green? features.
